    About This Guide

    This document provides helpful reference information for the REST API requests that you can send to the FODIM API. This document is intended for the technical personnel who customize and deploy this optimized solution according to the requirements of the end customer.

    Introduction to Framework for Open Distributed Manageability(FODIM)

    Welcome to the FODIM API!

    Managing a multitude of IT infrastructure devices of different make and type is something of a task, especially, when they exist across multiple locations. With the help of the FODIM API and a set of plugins(generic Redfish plugin and vendor-specific plugins such as HPE iLO, CFM), you can virtually bring all the devices(compute, storage, and networking) to be managed in one place.

    The FODIM API is a programming interface enabling easy and secure management of wide range of southbound equipment distributed across multiple data centers.

    The APIs exposed by the FODIM are organized around REST and are designed as per DMTF's Redfish® Scalable Platforms API(Redfish) specification 2019.3 DSP2046.

    All request and response bodies, including errors, are in JSON format.

    Key benefits of the FODIM API

    • Comprehensive lifecycle management of southbound infrastructure: the FODIM API maintains a central repository of southbound equipment and simplifies device discovery, configuration, monitoring, and administration of all devices.

    • Scalable: leveraging the resource aggregation capability of the FODIM API, you can manage a wide range of different southbound devices(from stand-alone to rack mount and bladed to large-scale environments).

    • Simplifies interaction of northbound clients with southbound systems: the FODIM API offers a protocol-independent eventing mechanism using which northbound clients get notified of alarms from southbound equipment.

    FODIM logical architecture

    The FODIM based on Redfish standards uses RESTful API to create an environment that is designed to be implemented on many different models of servers and other IT infrastructure devices for years to come. These devices may be quite different from one another. For this reason, the Redfish API does not specify the URIs to various resources.

    Using the FODIM API

    The FODIM API is available on version __ or later.

    To access the RESTful APIs, you need an HTTPS-capable client, such as a web browser with a REST Client plugin extension, or a Desktop REST Client application (such as Postman), or cURL (a popular, free command line utility). You can also easily write simple REST clients for RESTful APIs using modern scripting languages.

    Tip: It is good to use a tool, such as cURL or Postman initially to perform requests. Later, you will want to write your own scripting code to do this.

    Note: The examples shown in this document use cURL to make HTTP requests.

    Curl is a command line tool which helps you get or send information through URLs using supported protocols(HTTP in the case of FODIM). It is available at http://curl.haxx.se/ .

    All the cURL examples use the following options(flags):

    • --insecure bypasses validation of the HTTPS certificate. In actual usage, the FODIM RESTful API should be configured to use a user-supplied certificate and this option is not necessary.

    • -i returns HTTP response headers.

    HTTP Request Methods, Responses, and Error Codes for FODIM REST API

    Following are the Redfish defined HTTP methods that you can use to implement various actions:

    HTTP Request Methods Description
    GET [Read Requests] Use this method to request a representation of a specified resource (single resource or collection).
    PATCH [Update] Use this method to apply partial modifications to a resource.
    POST [Create] [Actions] Use this method to create a new resource. Submit this request to the resource collection to which you want to add the new resource. You can also use this method to initiate operations on an object.
    DELETE [Delete] Use this method to delete a resource.

    The FODIM Redfish supports the following responses:

    Responses Description
    Metadata responses Describes the resources and types exposed by the service to generic clients.
    Resource responses Response in JSON format for an individual resource.
    Resource collection responses Response in JSON format for a collection of a resources.
    Error responses In case of an HTTP error, a high level JSON response is provided with additional information

    HTTP status codes

    Following are the HTTP Status codes with their descriptions:

    Status Code
    		 Description
    200 OK Successful completion of the request with representation in the body
    201 Created A new resource is successfully created with the Location header set to well-defined URI for the newly created resource. The response body includes the representation of the newly created resource.
    202 Accepted The request has been accepted for processing but not processed. The Location header is set to URI of a task monitor that can be queried later for the status of the operation.
    204 No content The request was a success but no content was returned in the body of the response.
    301 Moved Permanently The requested resource resides in a different URI given by the Location headers.
    302 Found The requested resource temporarily resides in a different URI.
    304 Not Modified When the service has performed conditional GET request but the resource content has not changed.
    400 Bad Request The request could not be performed due to missing or invalid information. An extended error message is returned in the response body.
    401 Unauthorized Missing or invalid authentication credentials included with a request.
    403 Forbidden The server recognizes the credentials to be not having the necessary authorization to perform the operation.
    404 Not Found The request specified the URI of a non-existing resource.
    405 Method Not Allowed When the HTTP verb specified in the request (GET, PATCH, DELETE, and so on) is not supported for a particular request URI. The response includes "Allow" header that lists the supported methods.
    406 Not Acceptable When the resource fails to generate a response that matches the media types specified in the Accept header.
    409 Conflict A creation or an update cannot be completed because it would conflict with the current state of the resources supported by the platform.
    410 Gone When the requested resource is no longer available in the server and there is no forwarding address available as well. This condition is expected to be considered permanent. Clients with hyperlink editing capabilities SHOULD delete references to the Request-URI after user approval. If the server does not know, or has no facility to determine, whether or not the condition is permanent, the status code 404 (Not Found) SHOULD be used instead. This response is cacheable unless indicated otherwise.
    411 Length Required When the content of the length is not specified using the Content-Length header.
    412 Precondition Failed When pre-condition (OData-version) checks fail.
    415 Unsupported Media Type When the Content-type specified for the body does not match.
    428 Precondition Required When the request does not provide the pre-condition such as an If-Match
    431 Request Header Field Too Large When the individual header or all the header fields in a request are too large, the server does not fulfils the request.
    500 Internal Server Error When the server encounters and unexpected condition that prevents it from fulfilling the request.
    501 Not Implemented When the server does not recognize or supports the method for any resource.
    503 Service Unavailable When the server is currently unable to service the request due to temporary overloading or maintenance.
    507 Insufficient Storage When the size of the response is too big for the server to build the response.

    Authenticating HTTP requests

    Following authentication methods can be implemented to authenticate requests to the FODIM REST API:

    • HTTP BASIC authentication

      You can implement HTTP BASIC authentication by providing valid FODIM user name and password in an HTTP Authorization: Basic header.

    curl -i --insecure -X GET\
-H 'Accept:application/json' \
-H 'Authorization:Basic {username}:{password}' \
'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AggregationService'

    • Redfish session login authentication

      You can implement Redfish Session Login Authentication by creating a Redfish login session through session management interface. To learn more about a session, see Creating and managing sessions section.

      Every session that is created has an authentication token called X-AUTH-TOKEN associated with it.

      To authenticate subsequent requests, provide this token in the X-AUTH-TOKEN request header.

    curl -i --insecure -X GET \
-H 'Accept:application/json' \
-H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AggregationService'

    NOTE:

    • When Basic Auth is used, a session is not created.

    • If you perform an HTTP operation(without providing authentication) on resources other than those mentioned below, you will receive an HTTP 401 unauthorized error.

      Resource URI Description
      The Redfish service root GET /redfish The URI for the Redfish Service Root. It returns the Redfish services' version.
      The list of Redfish services GET /redfish/v1 It returns a list of available services.
      The $metadata GET /redfish/v1/$metadata the Redfish Metadata Document.
      The OData Service Document GET /redfish/v1/odata the Redfish OData Service Document.
      The Sessions resource POST /redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions Creates a Redfish login session.

    • An X-AUTH-TOKEN is valid and a session is open only for 30 minutes, unless the user continues to send requests to a Redfish service using this token.

    • An idle session is automatically terminated after the timeout interval.

    List of supported APIs

    The FODIM Redfish supports the following APIs:

    URI Operation Applicable
    /redfish GET
    /redfish/v1 GET
    /redfish/v1/odata GET
    /redfish/v1/$metadata GET
    /redfish/v1/SessionService GET
    /redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions POST, GET
    /redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions/{session id} GET, DELETE
    /redfish/v1/AccountService GET
    /redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts POST, GET
    /redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/{Account id} GET, DELETE, PATCH
    /redfish/v1/AccountService/PrivilegeRegistry GET
    /redfish/v1/AccountService/Roles POST, GET
    /redfish/v1/AccountService/Roles/{Roles id} GET, DELETE, PATCH
    /redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.Add POST
    /redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.Remove POST
    /redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.Reset POST
    /redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.SetDefaultBootOrder POST
    /redfish/v1/Systems GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId} GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/Memory GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/MemoryDomains GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/NetworkInterfaces GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/EthernetInterfaces GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/bios GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/SecureBoot GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/Storage GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/Processors GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/Memory/{MemoryId} GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/EthernetInterfaces/{Id} GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/Processors/{Id} GET
    /redfish/v1/Chassis GET
    /redfish/v1/Chassis/{ComputerSystemId} GET
    /redfish/v1/Chassis/{ComputerSystemId}/Thermal GET
    /redfish/v1/Chassis/{ComputerSystemId}/NetworkAdapters GET
    /redfish/v1/Chassis/{ComputerSystemId}/Power GET
    /redfish/v1/Systems?filter={searchKeys}%20{conditionKeys}%20{value} GET
    /redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions POST
    /redfish/v1/Fabrics GET
    /redfish/v1/Fabrics/{fabricID} GET
    /redfish/v1/Fabrics/{fabricID}/Switches GET
    /redfish/v1/Fabrics/{fabricID}/Switches/{switchID} GET
    /redfish/v1/Fabrics/{fabricID}/Switches/{switchID}/Ports
    		 GET
    /redfish/v1/Fabrics/{fabricID} /Switches/{switchID}/Ports/{portid}
    		 GET
    /redfish/v1/TaskService GET
    /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks GET
    /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/{TaskID} GET
    /taskmon/{TaskID} GET

    NOTE:

    *ComputerSystemId is FODIM specified unique id of the server. It is represented as {UUID}:{n} in the FODIM API( Example : ba0a6871-7bc4-5f7a-903d-67f3c205b08c:1 )

    Viewing the list of supported Redfish services

    Method GET
    URI /redfish/v1
    Description The URI for the Redfish Service Root.
    Returns All the available services in the Service Root.
    Response Code 200 on success 
    curl -i GET \
              'https://FODIM_IP\_address/redfish/v1'

    Sample Response header 

    status:200

content-type:application/json; charset=UTF-8

x-frame-options:sameorigin
content-length:799 bytes
date:Wed,
13 Nov 2019 10:23:52 GMT+7m 16s

    Sample Response body

}

    Creating and managing sessions

    A session represents a window of user's login with a Redfish service and contains details about the user and the user activity. You can run multiple sessions simultaneously on FODIM.

    The FODIM offers Redfish SessionService interface for managing sessions and exposes APIs to achieve the following:

    • Creating a session

    • Listing active sessions

    • Deleting a session

    Supported APIs

    • /redfish/v1/SessionService

    • /redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions

    • /redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions/{session id}

    Creating a session

    Method POST
    URI /redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions
    Description This endpoint is used to create a session to implement authentication. Creating a session allows you to obtain an X-AUTH-TOKEN which is then used to authenticate other services.
    Authentication No authentication is required.
    Returns An X-AUTH-TOKEN header containing session authentication token.
    A Location header that contains a link to the newly created session instance.
    Message in the JSON response body saying that the session is created .
    Response Code 201 on success


    Note:

    It is a good practice to make note of the session authentication token returned in the X-AUTH-TOKEN header and session id returned in the Location header. You will need the session authentication token to authenticate subsequent requests to the FODIM API and the session id to log out later.

    curl --insecure -X POST \
   -H "Content-Type:application/json" \
   -d \
'{
"UserName": "{username},
"Password": "{password}"
}' \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions'

    Request URI parameters

    Parameter Type Description
    Username string User name for the user account for this session.
    Password string Password for the user account for this session.

    Sample Request body

    {
"Username": "abc",
"Password": "abc123"
}

    Sample Response header

    Cache-Control: no-cache
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type: application/json; charset=UTF-8
Etag: W/"02C2D1BB"
Link: </redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions/1a547199-0dd3-42de-9b24-1b801d4a1e63/>; rel=self
Location: \{FODIM\_IP_address\}/redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions/1a547199-0dd3-42de-9b24-1b801d4a1e63
Odata-Version: 4.0
**X-Auth-Token: 46987bb2-0df7-44c1-8668-44f2ec86dbe3**
X-Frame-Options: sameorigin
Date:
Thu, 22 Aug 2019 21:23:21 GMT+6m 30s
Transfer-Encoding: chunked

    Sample Response body

    "error":{
"code": "iLO.0.10.ExtendedInfo",
"message": "See @Message.ExtendedInfo for more information.",
"@Message.ExtendedInfo":[
{
"MessageId": "Base.1.0.Created"
}
]
}
}

    Listing the active sessions

    Method GET
    URI /redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions
    Description This endpoint retrieves a list of active sessions.
    Authentication X-AUTH-TOKEN Authorization or Basic Authorization.
    Returns A list of active user sessions.
    Response Code 200 on success 
    curl --insecure -X GET \
-H 'Accept:application/json' \
-H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
'https://FODIM_IP_address/redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions'

    Sample Response header

    Viewing information about a single session

    Method GET
    URI /redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions/{session id}
    Description A specific user session.
    Authentication X-AUTH-TOKEN Authorization or Basic Authorization.
    Returns Details of this session.
    Response Code 200 on success 
    curl --insecure -X GET \
-H 'Accept:application/json' \
-H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
'https://FODIM_IP_address/redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions/{session id}'


    NOTE:

    Replace {session id} with the Session Id returned in the Location header from session creation.

    Sample Response header

    Cache-Control:  no-cache
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type:   application/json; charset=utf-8
Etag:   W/"16B6EF53"
Odata-Version:  4.0
X-Frame-Options:    sameorigin
Date:   Thu, 12 Sep 2019 19:27:48 GMT+6m 2s
Transfer-Encoding:  chunked

    Sample Response body

    {
"@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#Session.Session",
"@odata.etag": "W/\"16B6EF53\"",
"@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions/1e0492f8-112d-4f9a-8102-a87bf5706d1f",
"@odata.type": "#Session.v1_0_0.Session",
"ID": "1e0492f8-112d-4f9a-8102-a87bf5706d1f",
"Description": "Manager Bruce Session",
"Name": "Bruce Session",
"Oem":{},
"UserName": "abc"
}

    Deleting a session

    Method DELETE
    URI /redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions/{sessions id}
    Description DELETE method on this endpoint is used to terminate a specific Redfish session when the user logs out.
    Authentication X-AUTH-TOKEN Authorization or Basic Authorization.
    Response Code 200 on success


    NOTE: - A user with operator privileges can delete a session using the Session ID and the X-AUTH-TOKEN that they created. - A user with admin privileges can delete any active session.

    curl --insecure -X DELETE \
-H 'Accept:application/json' \
-H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
'https://FODIM_IP_address/redfish/v1/SessionService/Sessions/{session id}'

    Sample response header

    Cache-Control:  no-cache
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type:   application/json; charset=utf-8
Etag:   W/"16B6EF53"
Odata-Version:  4.0
X-Frame-Options:    sameorigin
Date:   Thu, 12 Sep 2019 19:40:08 GMT+6m 2s
Transfer-Encoding:  chunked

    Sample response body

    none

    Configuring roles and privileges for a user

    The FODIM API supports role-based authorization of requests - the roles and privileges control which users have what access to resources.

    Roles

    A role represents a set of operations that a user is allowed to perform and is determined by a defined set of privileges. The privileges of a role are configurable - you can choose a privilege or a set of privileges to assign to a role at the time of role creation.

    See Creating a role.

    With FODIM, there are two kinds of defined roles:

    • Redfish pre-defined roles

      Redfish pre-defined roles come with a pre-defined set of privileges. You can assign additional OEM privileges. Following are the Redfish pre-defined roles:

      • Administrator
      • Operator
      • ReadOnly

    • OEM(Original Equipment Manufacturer) roles

      OEM roles are the custom roles that you can create and assign to a user. Following are the available OEM roles:

      • admin : The admin is an OEM pre-defined role that has all the privileges needed to manage all services. The admin can perform any actions such as adding and removing equipments, adding or removing users or privileges, and so on.
      • client : The client is an OEM role that uses the northbound APIs to manage the southbound infrastructure.
      • monitor : The Monitor is an OEM role that is used typically by northbound monitoring solutions, this user role performs actions such as setting up subscriptions to be notified on Alerts from southbound infrastructure.

    NOTE:

    Every user is assigned one role at the time of user account creation; ensure that an OEM role is created before assigning it to a user at the time of user account creation.

    Privileges

    A privilege is a permission to perform an operation or a set of operations within a defined management domain. There are Redfish specified set of privileges as well as OEM-defined privileges.

    The following privileges can be assigned to any user in FODIM:

    • ConfigureComponents : Users with this privilege can configure components managed by the services in FODIM Redfish API.

    • ConfigureManager : Users with this privilege can configure manager resources.

    • ConfigureSelf : Users with this privilege can change the password for their account.

    • ConfigureUsers : Users with this privilege can configure users and their accounts. This privilege is assigned to an administrator.

    • Login : Users with this privilege can log into the service and read the resources.

    NOTE:

    The privileges set for a Redfish pre-defined role cannot be modified.

    Mapping of privileges to roles in the FODIM API

    Roles Assigned privileges
    Administrator (Redfish pre-defined) - Login
    - ConfigureManager
    - ConfigureUsers
    - ConfigureComponents
    - ConfigureSelf
    Operator (Redfish pre-defined) - Login
    - ConfigureComponents
    - ConfigureSelf
    ReadOnly (Redfish pre-defined) - Login
    - ConfigureSelf
    admin (OEM)
    client (OEM)
    monitor (OEM)

    Creating a role

    Method POST
    URI /redfish/v1/AccountService/Roles
    Description This operation creates a role that will be used by the AccountService to create a user account.
    Response Code 201 Created on success

    NOTE:

    Only a user with ConfigureUsers privilege can perform this operation.

    curl --insecure -X POST \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
   -H "Content-Type:application/json" \
   -d \
'{
  "id": "{SomeRole}",
  "AssignedPrivileges": [{Set_of_Redfish_privileges}],
  "OemPrivileges": [{Set_of_OEM_privileges}]
}' \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AccountService/Roles'

    Sample Request body

    {
  "id": "ADMIN",
  "AssignedPrivileges": ["Login","ConfigureManager","ConfigureUsers","ConfigureSelf","ConfigureComponents"],
  "OemPrivileges": []
}

    Request URI parameters

    Parameter Type Description
    id string User name for the user account.
    AssignedPrivileges array (string (enum)) The redfish privileges that this role includes. See FODIM Redfish API User roles and Privileges
    OemPrivileges array (string) The OEM privileges that this role includes. See FODIM Redfish API User roles and Privileges

    Sample Response header

    Allow:  "GET", "DELTE", "PATCH", "HEAD"
Cache-Control:  no-cache
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type:   application/json; charset=utf-8
Etag:   W/"12345"
Link:   /v1/SchemaStore/en/ManagerAccount.json/>; rel=describedby
Odata-Version:  4.0
X-Frame-Options:    sameorigin
Date:   Fri, 13 Sep 2019 09:22:57 GMT+6m 38s
Transfer-Encoding:  chunked

    Sample Response body

    {
"@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#ManagerAccount.ManagerAccount",
"@odata.etag": "W/\"12345\"",
"@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/admin/",
"@odata.type": "#ManagerAccount.v1_1_3.ManagerAccount",
"UserName": "admin",
"RoleID": "ADMIN",
"Password": null,
"ID": "admin",
"Name": "User Account",
"Description": "Bruce user account",
"Links":{
"Role":{
"@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AccountService/Roles/ADMIN/"
}
},
"Oem":{}
}

    Listing roles

    Method GET
    URI /redfish/v1/AccountService/Roles
    Description GET on this endpoint retrieves a list of user roles.
    Returns Links to user role resources.
    Response Code 200 OK on success

    NOTE:

    Only a user with ConfigureUsers privileges can perform this operation.

    curl --insecure -X GET \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \

    Creating and managing user accounts

    The FODIM API allows users to have accounts to configure their actions and restrictions.

    A user other than admin needs to create an account by defining a user name, a password, and a role. The username and the password are used to establish a login session with the Redfish services later.

    It exposes Redfish AccountsService APIs to manage user accounts. Use these endpoints to perform the following operations:

    • Creating, modifying, and deleting account details.

    • Fetching account details.

    Supported APIs:

    • /redfish/v1/AccountService

    • /redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts

    • /redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/{Account Id}

    • /redfish/v1/AccountService/Roles

    • /redfish/v1/AccountService/Roles/{Role id}

    Creating an account

    Method POST
    URI /redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts
    Description POST method on this endpoint creates a user account.
    Returns A Location header that contains a link to the newly created account.
    The JSON response body containing the properties of the created account.
    Response Code 201 Created on success 
    curl --insecure -X POST \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
   -d \
'{"Username":"{username}","Password":"{password}","RoleId":"{roleId}"}
' \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts'

    Request URI parameters

    Parameter Type Description
    Username string User name for the user account.
    Password string Password for the user account. See "Password Requirements" section below.
    RoleId string The Role for this account. See FODIM Redfish API User roles and Privileges

    Password Requirements

    • Your password must not be same as your username.

    • Your password must be at least 12 characters long and at most 16 characters long. However, this length restriction is configurable.

    • Your password must contain at least one uppercase letter, one lowercase letter, one digit (0-9), and one special character.

    Sample Request body

    {
"Username": "test5",
"Password": "test123",
"RoleId": "MONITOR"
}

    Sample Response header

    Cache-Control:  
no-cache
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Type:   application/json; charset=utf-8
Etag:   W/"12345"
Link:   /v1/AccountService/Accounts/test5/>; rel=describedby
**Location: /redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/test5/**
Odata-Version:  4.0
X-Frame-Options:    sameorigin
Date:   
Tue, 17 Sep 2019 10:52:41 GMT+6m 41s
Transfer-Encoding:  chunked

    Sample Response body

    {
"@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#ManagerAccount.ManagerAccount",
"@odata.etag": "W/\"12345\"",
"@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/test5/",
"@odata.type": "#ManagerAccount.v1_1_3.ManagerAccount",

"Password": null,

"Description": "Bruce user account",

"@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AccountService/Roles/MONITOR/"
}
},
"Oem":{}
}

    Updating an account

    Method PATCH
    URI /redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/{accountId}
    Description PATCH method on this endpoint updates user account details such as username, password, and RoleId.
    Returns Message in the JSON response body saying that the account is modified.
    Response Code 200 OK on success 
    curl --insecure -X PATCH \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
   -H "Content-Type:application/json" \
   -d \
'{
"Password": "{new_password}"
}
' \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/{accountId}'

    NOTE:

    • Replace {accountId} with the username for the account whose details you want to update.

    • Add the account details (username, password, and RoleId) to be modified in the request payload.

    Sample Request body

    {
"Password": "test12",
"RoleId": "MONITOR"
}

    Aggregating and managing southbound infrastructure

    One of the state-of-the-art features of the FODIM API is that it allows users to add and group southbound infrastructure(servers, storage devices, or fabrics) into one aggregate for easy manageability. It offers Redfish AggregationService as an interface and exposes endpoints to achieve the following:

    • Adding a resource to manage and constructing its detailed inventory.

    • Resetting one or more resources.

    • Changing the boot path of one or more resources to default settings.

    • Removing a resource and its inventory.

    Using these endpoints, you can add or remove only one resource at a time. You can group the resources into one collection and perform actions such as reset and setdefaultbootorder in combination on that group.

    All aggragation actions are performed as tasks in the FODIM API. The actions performed on a group of resources(resetting or changing the boot order to default settings) are carried out as a set of sub-tasks.

    The next section contains the use case for server aggregation.

    Prerequisites

    • To access Redfish AggregationService endpoints, ensure that the user has ConfigureComponents privilege.

    Supported Endpoints

    • /redfish/v1/AggregatorService/Actions/AggregationService.Add

    • /redfish/v1/AggregatorService/Actions/AggregationService.Remove

    • /redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.Reset

    • /redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.SetDefaultBootOrder

    The aggregation service root

    Method GET
    URI redfish/v1/AggregationService
    Description The URI for the Aggregation service root.
    Returns Properties for the service and a list of actions you can perform using this service.
    Response Code 200 on success 
    curl -i --insecure -X GET \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AggregationService'

    Sample response header 

    allow:  GET
cache-control:  no-cache
content-length: 1 kilobytes
content-type:   application/json; charset=utf-8
date:   Mon, 18 Nov 2019 14:52:21 GMT+5h 37m
etag:   W/"12345"
link:   /v1/SchemaStore/en/AggregationService.json>; rel=describedby
odata-version:  4.0
status: 200
x-frame-options:    sameorigin

    Sample response body 

    { 
   "@odata.context":"/redfish/v1/$metadata#AggregationService.AggregationService",
   "@odata.etag":"W/\"979B45E7\"",
   "Id":"AggregationService",
   "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/AggregationService",
   "@odata.type":"#AggregationService.v1_0_0.AggregationService",
   "Name":"AggregationService",
   "Description":"AggregationService",
   "Actions":{ 
      "#AggregationService.Add":{

      },

         "target":"/redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.Remove/",

   }
}

    Use case for server aggregation

    Adding a server

    Method POST
    URI /redfish/v1/AggregatorService/Actions/AggregationService.Add
    Returns Location URI of the task monitor associated with this operation in the response header.
    Response Code 202 on success

    Description

    This action adds a single server and performs a detailed inventory of it. On success, ORCA specified Computer System Id is assigned to the added server.

    NOTE:

    Make note of the Computer System Id. You will need this to perform subsequent actions such as delete, reset, and setdefaultbootorder on this server.

    curl -i --insecure -X POST \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
   -H "Content-Type:application/json" \
   -d \
'{"ManagerAddress":"{Server_IP_Address}","UserName":"{Account_UserName}","Password":"{Account_Password}","Oem":{"PluginID":"{Redfish_PluginId}"}}' \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.Add'

    Sample request body

    {
    "ManagerAddress": "10.24.0.6",
    "Username": "username",
    "Password": "password",
    "Oem": {
        "PluginID": "GRF"
    }
}

    Request Parameters

    Parameter Type Description
    ManagerAddress A valid IP address or hostname of a baseboard management controller (BMC)
    Username string The username for this user account
    Password string The password for this user account
    PluginID string The plugin id Example : GRF (Generic Redfish Plugin)

    Sample response header

    content-length:0 byte
content-type:application/json; charset=utf-8
date:Thu,
07 Nov 2019 09:29:36 GMT+7m 8s
**location:/taskmon/taskb297ff4e-0d2d-485c-8217-63d888cba7d2**
odata-version:4.0
status:202
x-frame-options:sameorigin

    Sample response body

    None

    Knowing the addition status

    To know the status of the progress of this action, perform GET on the URI of the task monitor returned in the Location header.

    • If the task is still running, you will receive the following information in the JSON response indicating that the task is yet to complete:

      • Task state as "Running"
      • percentage of completion

    • If the task is complete(server is successfully added in the inventory), you will receive a link to the added server in the Location header and in the response body as well.

    Sample header: when the task status is running 

    status:202
allow:"GET"cache-control:no-cache
content-type:application/json; charset=utf-8
date:Wed,04 Dec 2019 12:30:59 GMT+5h 37m
etag:W/"12345"
location:/taskmon/taskac4d5b78-9ba8-46b4-b69b-0f3580aec2c2
odata-version:4.0
x-frame-options:sameorigin
content-length:691 bytes

    Sample response body: when the task is running

    { 
   "@odata.type":"#Task.v1_3_0.Task",
   "Id":"taskac4d5b78-9ba8-46b4-b69b-0f3580aec2c2",

   "Description":"",

    Sample response body: when the task status is complete

    { 
   "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Systems/bffb4a1b-0d19-4531-ba44-0ac83c77579d:1"
}

    Resetting one or more servers

    Method POST
    URI /redfish/v1/AggregatorService/Actions/AggregationService.Reset
    Returns Location URI of the task monitor associated with this operation in the response header.
    Response Code 202 on success

    Description

    This action shuts down, powers up, and restarts one or more servers.

    You can perform reset on a group of servers by specifying multiple target URIs in the request.

      curl -i --insecure -X POST \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
   -H "Content-Type:application/json" \
   -d \
'{
"@Redfish.Copyright": "Copyright 2018-2019 DMTF. All rights reserved.",
"@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#ActionInfo.ActionInfo",
"@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AggregationService/ResetActionInfo",
"@odata.type": "#ActionInfo.v1_0_3.ActionInfo",
"Id": "AddActionInfo",
"Name": "Reset Action Info",

 "Oem": {

  },

"parameters": {
"ResetCollection": {
"description": "Collection of ResetTargets",
"ResetTarget": [{
"ResetType": "ForceRestart",
"TargetUri": "/redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}"
},
{
"ResetType": "ForceOff",
"TargetUri": "/redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}"
}
]
}
}
}' \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.Reset'

    Sample request body

    { 
   "@Redfish.Copyright":"Copyright 2018-2019 DMTF. All rights reserved.",
   "@odata.context":"/redfish/v1/$metadata#ActionInfo.ActionInfo",
   "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/AggregationService/ResetActionInfo",
   "@odata.type":"#ActionInfo.v1_0_3.ActionInfo",
   "Id":"AddActionInfo",
   "Name":"Reset Action Info",
   "Oem":{ 

   },
   "parameters":{ 
      "ResetCollection":{ 
         "description":"Collection of ResetTargets",
         "ResetTarget":[ 
            { 
               "ResetType":"ForceRestart",
               "TargetUri":"/redfish/v1/Systems/f0c61692-a8dc-46ce-b85c-bf4753c3abdf:1"
            },
            { 
               "ResetType":"ForceOff",
               "TargetUri":"/redfish/v1/Systems/24b243cf-f1e3-5318-92d9-2d6737d6b0b9:1"
            }
         ]
      }
   }
}

    Request Parameters

    Parameter Type Description
    @odata.context string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters section.
    @odata.id string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters section.
    @odata.type string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters section.
    Id string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters section.
    Name string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters section.
    Oem object Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters section.
    parameters[ { array The parameters associated with the Reset Action.
    ResetType string The type of reset to be performed. See "Reset Type" section below, for the possible values of this property.
    TargetUri } ] string The URI of the target for Reset - "/redfish/v1/Systems/<ComputerSystemId>"

    Reset Type

    string Description
    ForceOff Turn the unit off immediately (non-graceful shutdown).
    ForceOn Turn the unit on immediately.
    ForceRestart Perform an immediate (non-graceful) shutdown, followed by a restart.
    GracefulRestart Perform a graceful shutdown followed by a restart of the system.
    GracefulShutdown Perform a graceful shutdown. Graceful shutdown involves shutdown of the operating system followed by the power off of the physical server.
    Nmi Generate a Diagnostic Interrupt (usually an NMI on x86 systems) to cease normal operations, perform diagnostic actions and typically halt the system.
    On Turn the unit on.
    PowerCycle Perform a power cycle of the unit.
    PushPowerButton Simulate the pressing of the physical power button on this unit.

    Sample Response header

    content-length: 0 byte
content-type:   application/json; charset=utf-8
date:   Fri, 08 Nov 2019 07:49:42 GMT+7m 9s
location:   /taskmon/taska9702e20-884c-41e2-bd9c-d779a4dd2e6e
odata-version:  4.0
status: 202
x-frame-options:    sameorigin

    Sample response body

    None

    Knowing the reset status

    Resetting a group of servers is carried out as a set of sub-tasks: each sub-task resets a single server in the group.

    Perform GET on the URI of the task monitor returned in the Location header.

    • If the task is yet to complete, you will receive the following information in the response body:

      • An HTTP 202 Accepted response.
      • Link to the list of sub-tasks associated with this group of servers. Perform GET on an individual sub-task link to know the status of the reset action on the respective server.
      • Task status as "running".

    • In case of errors, you will receive the following information:

      • HTTP error code
      • Error Message having a link to the main reset task in the response body. Copy this link and perform GET to view the list of sub-tasks. To know which sub-tasks have failed, perform GET on the links individually.

    • If all the servers are successfully reset, you will receive an HTTP 200 OK response and a success message in the response body.

    Sample response header: when the task is complete

    cache-control:  no-cache
content-length: 469 bytes
content-type:   application/json; charset=utf-8
date:   Mon, 18 Nov 2019 09:42:45 GMT+7m 22s
etag:   W/"12345"
odata-version:  4.0
status: 200
x-frame-options: sameorigin

    Sample response body: when the task is complete

      { 
   "error":{ 
      "code":"Base.1.0.Success",
      "message":"An error has occurred. See ExtendedInfo for more information.",
      "@Message.ExtendedInfo":[ 
         { 
            "@odata.type":"#Message.v1_0_6.Message",
            "MessageId":"Base.1.0.Success",
            "Message":"default error message all reset actions are successfully completed. for more information please check SubTasks in URI: /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/task87f5825f-db3b-40f7-af07-d8d5781245cd",
            …
         }
      ]
   }
}

    **Sample response body in case of a failure

    { 
   "error":{ 
      "code":"Base.1.0.Success",
      "message":"An error has occurred. See ExtendedInfo for more information.",
      "@Message.ExtendedInfo":[ 
         { 
            "@odata.type":"#Message.v1_0_6.Message",
            "MessageId":"Base.1.0.Success",
            "Message":"default error message one or more of the reset actions failed. for more information please check SubTasks in URI: /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/taskb8ab3688-1d1f-4143-abcc-fe05b0fbac79",
            …
         }
      ]
   }
}

    Changing the boot order of a set of servers to default settings

    Method POST
    URI /redfish/v1/AggregatorService/Actions/AggregationService.SetDefaultBootOrder
    Returns Location URI of the Task Monitor associated with this operation in the response header.
    Response Code 202 Accepted on success

    Description

    This action changes the boot order of one or more servers to default settings.

    You can perform setDefaultBootOrder on a group of servers by specifying multiple server URIs in the request.

    curl -i --insecure -X POST \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
   -H "Content-Type:application/json" \
   -d \
'{ 

"@Redfish.Copyright": "Copyright 2018-2019 DMTF. All rights reserved.", 

 "@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#ActionInfo.ActionInfo", 

 "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AggregationService/SetDefaultBootOrderActionInfo", 

                 "@odata.type": "#ActionInfo.v1_0_3.ActionInfo", 

                 "Id": "AddActionInfo", 

                 "Name": "SetDefaultBootOrder Action Info", 

                  "parameters": { 

                  "ServerCollection": [ 

"/redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}", 

"/redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}" 

] 

} 

}' \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.SetDefaultBootOrder'

    Sample request body

    { 
   "@Redfish.Copyright":"Copyright 2018-2019 DMTF. All rights reserved.",
   "@odata.context":"/redfish/v1/$metadata#ActionInfo.ActionInfo",
   "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/AggregationService/SetDefaultBootOrderActionInfo",
   "@odata.type":"#ActionInfo.v1_0_3.ActionInfo",
   "Id":"AddActionInfo",
   "Name":"SetDefaultBootOrder Action Info",
   "parameters":{ 
      "ServerCollection":[ 
         "/redfish/v1/Systems/97d08f36-17f5-5918-8082-f5156618f58d:1",
         "/redfish/v1/Systems/76632110-1c75-5a86-9cc2-471325983653:1"
      ]
   }
}

    Request Parameters

    Parameter Type Description
    @odata.context string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    @odata.id string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    @odata.type string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    Id string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    Name string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    parameters[ { array The parameters associated with the SetDefaultBootOrder Action.
    ServerCollection } ]
    		 Target servers for setDefaultBootOrder

    Sample response header

    status: 202
content-type:   application/json; charset=utf-8
**location: /taskmon/task7c1b4b6c-8e46-4fb6-a66a-6f629c10d827**
odata-version:  4.0
x-frame-options:    sameorigin
content-length: 0 byte
date:   
Fri, 08 Nov 2019 08:13:40 GMT+7m 10s

    Sample response body

    None

    Knowing the change status

    Changing the boot order to default settings on a group of servers is carried out as a set of sub-tasks: each sub-task resets a single server in the group.

    Perform GET on the URI of the task monitor returned in the Location header.

    • If the task is yet to complete, you will receive the following information in the response body:

      • An HTTP 202 Accepted response.
      • Link to the list of sub-tasks associated with this group of servers. Perform GET on an individual sub-task link to know the status of the reset action on the respective server.
      • Task status as "running".

    • In case of errors, you will receive the following information:

      • An HTTP error code.
      • An error message having a link to the main reset task in the response body. Copy this link and perform GET to view the list of sub-tasks. To know which sub-tasks have failed, perform GET on the links individually.

    • If the action is successful, you will receive an HTTP 200 OK response and a success message in the response body.

    **Sample response body in case of a failure

    { 
   "error":{ 
      "code":"Base.1.0.Success",
      "message":"An error has occurred. See ExtendedInfo for more information.",
      "@Message.ExtendedInfo":[ 
         { 
            "@odata.type":"#Message.v1_0_6.Message",
            "MessageId":"Base.1.0.Success",
            "Message":"default error message one or more of the SetDefaultBootOrder requests failed. for more information please check SubTasks in URI: /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/task7fd888a8-26f3-489f-98b6-2287aae1c76f",
            …
         }
      ]
   }
}

    Deleting a server

    Method POST
    URI /redfish/v1/AggregatorService/Actions/AggregationService.Remove
    Returns Location URI of the Task Monitor associated with this operation in the response header.
    Response Code 202 Accepted on success

    Description

    This action removes a specific server and deletes its inventory.

    To know the status of the progress of this operation, perform GET on the URI of the task monitor returned in the Location header. If the server is successfully removed from the inventory, you will receive an HTTP 200 OK response.

    curl -i --insecure -X POST \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
   -H "Content-Type:application/json" \
   -d \
'{
"@Redfish.Copyright": "Copyright 2018-2019 DMTF. All rights reserved.",
"@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#ActionInfo.ActionInfo",
"@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AggregationService/RemoveActionInfo",
"@odata.type": "#ActionInfo.v1_0_3.ActionInfo",
"Id": "RemoveActionInfo",
"Name": "Remove Action Info",
"Oem": "",
"parameters": [
{
"Name": "/redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}"
}
]
}' \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.Remove/'

    Sample request body

    {
    "@Redfish.Copyright": "Copyright 2018-2019 DMTF. All rights reserved.",
    "@odata.context": "/redfish/v1/$metadata#ActionInfo.ActionInfo",
    "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AggregationService/RemoveActionInfo",
    "@odata.type": "#ActionInfo.v1_0_3.ActionInfo",
    "Id": "AddActionInfo",
    "Name": "Remove Action Info",
    "Oem": "",
    "parameters": [
        {
            "Name": "/redfish/v1/Systems/97d08f36-17f5-5918-8082-f5156618f58d:1"
        }
    ]
}

    Request Parameters

    Parameter Type Description
    @odata.context string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    @odata.id string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    @odata.type string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    Id string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    Name string Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    Oem object Refer to Common Redfish Schema parameters.
    parameters[ { array The parameters associated with the Delete Action.
    Name } ]
    		 string The URI of the target to be removed - "/redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}"

    Sample response header

    content-length: 0 byte
content-type:   application/json; charset=utf-8
date:   Fri, 08 Nov 2019 05:49:05 GMT+7m 10s
**location: /taskmon/taskd5bba4ec-35a3-43cc-a058-9634c488a488**
odata-version:  4.0
status: 202
x-frame-options:    sameorigin

    Sample response body

    None

    Viewing the resource inventory

    The FODIM API allows you to view the inventory of managed southbound equipment through Redfish SystemService endpoints. It also offers the capability to search the inventory based on one or more resource configuration parameters.

    Perform GET on these endpoints to discover crucial configuration information about a resource(such as CPU utilization, memory utilization, processor power consumption).

    Prerequisites

    • Ensure that the user has a minimum privilege of Login.
    Inventory URI Description
    System overview /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId} A collection of endpoints to system node instances that are available in the inventory.
    Memory overview /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/Memory Information on memory device configuration such as capacity, total size, logical memory size, location and so on
    Memory /redfish/v1/Systems/<ComputerSystemId>/Memory/{memoryId} Configuration information of a memory.
    MemoryDomains /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/MemoryDomains Information on memory domain and its configuration
    EthernetInterfaces /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/EthernetInterfaces Information on Ethernet Interfaces or network interface controller(NIC).
    EthernetInterface /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/EthernetInterfaces/{EthernetInterfaceId} Information on a single, logical Ethernet Interface or network interface controller(NIC).
    Bios /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/bios System-specific information about a BIOS resource
    SecureBoot /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/SecureBoot Information on UEFI Secure Boot and managing the UEFI Secure Boot functionality of a system.
    Storage subsystem /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/Storage A storage subsystem is a set of storage controllers(physical or virtual) and the resources such as volumes that can be accessed from that subsystem.
    Processors /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/Processors
    Single processor /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/Processors/{processorId} The properties of a processor
    NetworkInterface /redfish/v1/Systems/{ComputerSystemId}/NetworkInterfaces A NetworkInterface contains links to NetworkAdapter, NetworkPort, and NetworkDeviceFunction resources.
    Chassis /redfish/v1/Chassis/{ComputerSystemId} Information on a specific Chassis instance. Chassis represents the physical components of a system - sheet-metal confined spaces, logical zones such as racks, enclosures, chassis and all other containers, and Subsystems (like sensors).
    Network adapters /redfish/v1/Chassis/{ComputerSystemId}/NetworkAdapters Information on NetworkAdapters. Some examples of NetworkAdapters include Ethernet, Fibre Channel, and converged network adapters.
    Thermal /redfish/v1/Chassis/{ComputerSystemId}/Thermal Information on the temperature and cooling of the entire Chassis.
    Power /redfish/v1/Chassis/{ComputerSystemId}/Power Information on processor power consumption and power limiting

    Search and filter

    Method GET
    URI /redfish/v1/Systems?filter={searchKeys}%20{conditionKeys}%20{value}
    Description Use this endpoint to search servers based on a keyword, a condition, and a value which are combined as filter in the request. Two ore more filters can be combined in a single request with the help of logical operands.
    Returns Server endpoints based on the specified filter.
    Response Code 200 OK 
    curl -X GET \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/Systems?filter={searchKeys}%20{conditionKeys}%20{value}%20{logicalOperand}%20{searchKeys}%20{conditionKeys}%20{value}'

    NOTE:

    Ensure that the user has Login privilege at the minimum.

    Sample curl usage 

    curl -X GET \
      -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
    'http://FODIM_IP_address/redfish/v1/Systems?filter=MemorySummary/TotalSystemMemoryGiB%20eq%20384'


    Request URI Parameters

    1. {searchkeys} refers to ComputerSystem parameters. Following are the allowed search keys:

    - "ProcessorSummary/Count"

    - "ProcessorSummary/Model"

    - "SystemType"

    - "MemorySummary/TotalSystemMemoryGiB"

    - " ProcessorSummary/sockets"

    1. {conditionKeys} refers to Redfish specified conditions. Following are the allowed condition keys:

      Condition Key Meaning
      "eq" Equal to
      "ne" Not equal to
      "gt" Greater than
      "ge" Greater than or equal to
      "le" Lesser than or equal to
      "lt" Lesser than

    2. {value} refers to the actual value of the search parameter.

    3. {logicalOperands} refers to the logical operands that are used to combine two or more filters in a request. Allowed logical operands are and, or, and not.

    Sample filter Description
    Simple filter(without logical operand): filter=TotalSystemMemoryGiB%20eq%20384
    		This filter searches a server having total physical memory of 384 GB
    Compound filter(with logical operands): filter=(ProcessorSummary/Count%20eq%202%20and%20ProcessorSummary/Model%20eq%20intel)%20and%20(TotalSystemMemoryGiB%20eq%20384)
    		This filter searches a server having total physical memory of 384 GB and Intel processor having the count of 2

    Sample Response header 

    status:200
allow:"GET"cache-control:no-cache
content-type:application/json; charset=utf-8
etag:W/"12345"odata-version:4.0
x-frame-options:sameorigin
content-length:328 bytes
date:Tue,
05 Nov 2019 08:42:39 GMT+7m 7s

    Sample Response body 

    { 
   "@odata.context":"/redfish/v1/$metadata#ComputerSystemCollection.ComputerSystemCollection",
   "@odata.etag":"W/\"AA6D42B0\"",
   "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Systems/",
   "@odata.type":"#ComputerSystemCollection.ComputerSystemCollection",
   "Description":"Computer Systems view",
   "Name":"Computer Systems",
   "Members":[ 
      { 
         "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Systems/7ff3bd97-c41c-5de0-937d-85d390691b73:1"
      }
   ],
   "Members@odata.count":1
}

    Managing tasks

    A task represents an operation that takes more time than a user typically wants to wait and is carried out asynchronously.

    An example of a task is resetting an aggregate of servers. Resetting all the servers in a group is a time-consuming operation; the user waiting for the result would be blocked from performing other operations. The FODIM creates Redfish tasks for such long-duration operations and offers an interface for the users to manage them while performing other operations.

    The FODIM exposes Redfish TaskService APIs and Task monitor API. Use these endpoints to manage and monitor tasks till their completion.

    Prerequisites

    • Ensure that the user has Login privilege at the minimum.

    Supported Endpoints

    • /redfish/v1/TaskService

    • /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks

    • /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/{TaskID}

    • /taskmon/{TaskID}

    Viewing a Collection of tasks

    Method GET
    URI /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks
    Description A collection of tasks scheduled by or being executed by Redfish Task Service.
    Returns A list of task endpoints with task Ids.
    Response Code 200 on success 
      curl --insecure -X GET \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks'

    NOTE:

    Only an admin or a user with ConfigureUsers privilege can view all the running tasks in the FODIM API at a given point of time. Other users can view tasks created only for their operations.

    Sample Response header 

    allow:"GET"
cache-control:no-cache
content-length:345 bytes
content-type:application/json; charset=utf-8
date:Tue,05 Nov 2019 13:33:46 GMT+5h 37m
etag:W/"12345"
odata-version:4.0
status:200
x-frame-options:sameorigin

    Sample Response body 

    { 
   "@odata.context":"/redfish/v1/$metadata#TaskCollection.TaskCollection",
   "@odata.etag":"",
   "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks",
   "@odata.type":"#TaskCollection.TaskCollection",
   "Name":"Task Collection",
   "Description":"",
   "Members@odata.count":3,
   "Members":[ 
      { 
         "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/taskc8cf2e2e-6cb2-4e24-8512-247fa5d606b0"
      },
      { 
         "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/taskc15aca5a-30a6-4618-adca-c25c889dc409"
      },
      { 
         "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/task38d6df20-989f-4c05-ad0e-5939774bab7c"
      }
   ]
}

    Viewing information of a single task

    Method GET
    URI /redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/{TaskID}
    Description A specific task scheduled by or being executed by Redfish Task Service.
    Returns Details of this task - task Id, name, state of the task, start time and end time( in case task is complete) of this task, completion percentage, URI of the task monitor associated with this task, sub-tasks if any.
    Response Code 200 on success 
    curl --insecure -X GET \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/{TaskID}'

    Sample Response header 

    allow:"GET"
cache-control:no-cache
content-length:345 bytes
content-type:application/json; charset=utf-8
date:Tue,05 Nov 2019 13:33:46 GMT+5h 37m
etag:W/"12345"
odata-version:4.0
status:200
x-frame-options:sameorigin

    Sample Response body 

    { 
   "@odata.type":"#Task.v1_3_0.Task",
   "Id":"taskc15aca5a-30a6-4618-adca-c25c889dc409",
   "Name":"Task taskc15aca5a-30a6-4618-adca-c25c889dc409",
   "Description":"",
   "TaskState":"Completed",
   "StartTime":"2019-11-13 13:50:51.711162494 +0530 IST",
   "EndTime":"2019-11-13 08:21:26.64315461 +0000 UTC",
   "TaskStatus":"OK",
   "SubTasks":"/redfish/v1/Tasks/taskc15aca5a-30a6-4618-adca-c25c889dc409/SubTasks",
   "TaskMonitor":"/taskmon/taskc15aca5a-30a6-4618-adca-c25c889dc409",
   "PercentComplete":100,
   "Payload":{ 
      "HttpHeaders":{ 
         "Content-type":"application/json; charset=utf-8",
         "Location":"/redfish/v1/Systems/97d08f36-17f5-5918-8082-f5156618f58d:1"
      },
      "HttpOperation":"GET",
      "JsonBody":{ 
         "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/Systems/97d08f36-17f5-5918-8082-f5156618f58d:1"
      },
      "TargetUri":"/redfish/v1/AggregationService/Actions/AggregationService.Add"
   },
   "Messages":null,
   "@odata.context":"/redfish/v1/$metadata#Task.Task",
   "@odata.id":"/redfish/v1/TaskService/Tasks/taskc15aca5a-30a6-4618-adca-c25c889dc409"
}

    Monitoring a task through task monitor

    Method GET
    URI /taskmon/{TaskID}
    Description Task monitor allows for polling a specific task for its completion.
    Returns Result of the operation carried out by the task monitor.
    Response Code - 202 until the task is complete.
    - 200, 201 on success.
    		 
    curl --insecure -X GET \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
   -H "Content-Type:application/json" \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/taskmon/{TaskID}'

    Subscribing to events

    The FODIM offers an eventing interface that allows northbound clients to interact and receive notifications such as alarms from southbound equipment. It exposes Redfish EventService APIs as an interface for managing events.

    Events are messages provided by the service to asynchronously notify the client of some significant state change or error condition, usually of a time critical nature.

    Use these APIs to subscribe northbound clients to southbound events by creating a subscription entry in the service.

    Prerequisites

    • Ensure that Kafka is installed.

    • Ensure that the user has an administrator role or a client role.

    Supported Endpoints

    • redfish/v1/EventService

    • /redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions

    Creating an event subscription

    Method POST
    URI /redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions
    Description This endpoint subscribes one or more clients to an event by creating a subscription entry.
    Returns A Location header that contains a hyperlink to the newly created subscription.
    On success, a message in the JSON response body saying that the subscription is created.
    Response Code 201 
    curl --insecure -X POST \
   -H "X-Auth-Token:{X-Auth-Token}" \
   -H "Content-Type:application/json; charset=utf-8" \
   -d \
'{
                "Name": "subscription123",
                "Destination": "https://10.24.1.16:10002/redfish/v1/EventService/",
                "EventTypes": [
                  "Alert"
                ],
                "Context": "ABCDEFGHJLKJ",
                "Protocol": "Redfish",
                "SubscriptionType": "RedfishEvent",
                "EventFormatType": "Event",
                "SubordinateResources": true,
                "OriginResources": [
                   "/redfish/v1/Systems/{System Id}"
                ],
                    "Oem": {
                      "Hpe": { 
                          "DeliveryRetryIntervalInSeconds": 30, 
                          "RequestedMaxEventsToQueue": 20,
                          "DeliveryRetryAttempts": 5, 
                          "RetireOldEventInMinutes": 10 
                      } 
                  } 

}' \
 'https://{FODIM_IP_address}/redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions/'

    Sample Request body 

    {
                "Name": "subscription123",
                "Destination": "http://10.24.1.52:10002/redfish/v1/EventService/",
                "EventTypes": [
                  "Alert"
                ],
                "Context": "ABCDEFGHJLKJ",
                "Protocol": "Redfish",
                "SubscriptionType": "RedfishEvent",
                "EventFormatType": "Event",
                "SubordinateResources": true,
                "OriginResources": [
                   "/redfish/v1/Systems/76632110-1c75-5a86-9cc2-471325983653:1"
                ],
                    "Oem": {
                      "Hpe": { 
                          "DeliveryRetryIntervalInSeconds": 30, 
                          "RequestedMaxEventsToQueue": 20,
                          "DeliveryRetryAttempts": 5, 
                          "RetireOldEventInMinutes": 10 
                      } 
                  } 

              }

    Request Parameters

    Parameter Value Attributes Description
    Name string Name of the subscription.
    Destination string read-only required on create
    		 The URI of the destination Event Service.
    EventTypes array (string (enum)) read-only The types of events that will be sent to the destination.
    Context string read-write required (null)
    		 A client-supplied string that is stored with the event destination subscription.
    Protocol string (enum) read-only required on create
    		 The protocol type of the event connection.
    SubscriptionType string (enum) read-only required (null)
    		 Indicates the subscription type for events
    EventFormatType string (enum) read-only Indicates the content types of the message that this service can send to the event destination.
    SubordinateResources boolean read-only (null) This indicates if the service supports the SubordinateResource property on Event Subscriptions i.e.,subscription will be for events from the OriginsResources specified and also all subordinate resources.
    OriginResources array A list of resources for which the service will only send related events. If this property is absent or the array is empty, then Events originating from any resource will be sent to the subscriber.

    Event Types

    string Description
    Alert A condition exists which requires attention.
    MetricReport A metric report managed by the Telemetry Service is being sent.
    Other As of Redfish Specification v1.6, EventType has been deprecated. The event is therefore based on a Registry or Resource, not an EventType.
    ResourceAdded A resource has been added.
    ResourceRemoved A resource has been removed.
    ResourceUpdated The value of this resource has been updated.
    StatusChange The status of this resource has changed.

    EventFormatType

    string Description
    Event The subscription destination will receive JSON Bodies of the Resource Type Event.
    MetricReport The subscription destination will receive JSON Bodies of the Resource Type MetricReport.

    SubscriptionType

    string Description
    RedfishEvent The subscription follows the Redfish specification for event notifications, which is done by a service sending an HTTP POST to the subscriber's destination URI.
    SSE The subscription follows the HTML5 Server-Sent Event definition for event notifications.

    Protocol

    string Description
    Redfish The destination follows the Redfish specification for event notifications.

    *Source : Redfish Resource and Schema Guide

    Sample Response header 

    status: 201​
cache-control: no-cache​
content-type: application/json; charset=utf-8​
etag:  W/"12345"​
**location: /redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions/7e60f5bf-439c-4e14-acfd-ab4155257484**​
odata-version: 4.0​
x-frame-options: sameorigin​
content-length: 161 bytes​
date: Thu, 14 Nov 2019 10:26:48 GMT+7m 17s

    Sample Response body 

    { 
   ​   "error":​{ 
      ​      "@Message.ExtendedInfo":​[ 
         ​         { 
            ​            "MessageId":"Base.1.0.Created"            ​
         }         ​
      ],
      ​      "code":"iLO.0.10.ExtendedInfo",
      ​      "message":"See @Message.ExtendedInfo for more information."      ​
   }   ​
}​

    End-to-end use cases

    The basic use cases for the FODIM API include:

    1. Creating a user account

      Users other than admin need to create a user account by specifying a username, password, and a role before they can create a login session with the FODIM API.

      For examples, consult "Creating and managing user accounts" section.

    2. Creating a login session

      Create a login session with the FODIM API to obtain an X-AUTH-TOKEN which is required to authenticate subsequent requests(skip this if you choose Basic authetication method).

      For examples, consult "Creating and managing sessions" section.

    3. Adding the resources that you want to manage

      Add all the resources to be managed one by one. The FODIM API builds a detailed inventory of every resource that is added.

      For examples, consult "Aggregating and managing southbound equipment" section.

    4. Searching and viewing the resource inventory information

      The resource inventory contains crucial system details such as CPU details, memory details, chassis, power details. You can search the inventory based on a specific system parameter.

      For examples, consult "Accessing the inventory of a managed southbound resource" section.

    5. Managing the resource: performing actions on the resource

      Perform actions such as resetting, changing the boot order to default settings.

      For examples, consult "Aggregating and managing southbound equipment" section.

    6. Deleting a resource that is no longer managed

      Delete resources that you do not want to manage anymore.

      For examples, consult "Aggregating and managing southbound equipment" section.

    7. Managing tasks

      View and monitor a list of running tasks initiated by the user such as adding a resource, resetting, deleting.

      For examples, consult "Managing tasks" section.

    8. Subscribing to events

      Get notified of alarms from the southbound resources.

      For examples, consult Subscribing northbound clients to southbound events section.

    cURL
